translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully enlightened one
From the Characteristics
The Buddha’s Thirty Verses
In many existences,
You fulfilled the ten perfections;
And the practices of the Fully Enlightened One,🔽In generosity, you were like a swan.
In the state of Vessantara,
You stood and gave away your children;
Your own black antelope skin and matted hair,
Like the Vamkata mountain.

analyzed: tatas ca vi tvā tu site
translated: And having passed away from there,
In the Tusita heaven, you were reborn with merit;
In the ten realms beginning with form,
You surpassed the other gods.
In a thousand world systems,
In all ten directions,
Requested by gods and Brahmas,
You attained the state of Buddhahood.
And with the five kinds of observation,
The Lord of Sages observed;
And having passed away from there, in the Māyā clan,
You were reborn in the Sākiya clan.
In the best of the months, Visākha and Puṇṇama,
You were conceived in the Lumbinī grove;
Roaring a lion’s roar,

analyzed: satta pādaṃgatā utadā  virociṃsuta ākāse  tārā canda divākarā
translated: You took seven steps then.🔽The moon and sun in the sky
Shone forth, and the jewels on the ground,
And various flowers blossomed.
The fires of Avīci burned cool,
And thirst and hunger were satisfied;
In the world between, with great radiance,
Until the blind were cured.
Unstruck musical instruments,
Sounded in the sky;
Sweetly they played,
Until the world was filled with sound.
Singing songs of praise,🔽The gods, seated on lotus seats,
Rejoiced and waited,

analyzed: buddhaṅkurassa santike  kumāra ucārudhātīhi  tositā rāja mandire  vuddha usi su sukham khemam
translated: In the presence of the Buddha’s sprout.🔽In the royal palace, delighted by the prince’s good conduct,
The Sakyan princess was well, happy, and safe.
The Sakyan girl, sixteen years old,
With Nandopanandā as her companions,
Was anointed queen,
And rejoiced in her three modes of conduct.🔽The golden-hued Nandā,
With a beautiful complexion and breasts,
Was anointed as the great seer’s wife,
The world’s guide and delight.
In his twenty-ninth year,
On the full moon of Visākhā,
With a great army, he went
To the pleasure park by vehicle.
Seeing the four signs,
And hearing of his son’s birth,
Hearing, his mind was stirred,
And he came from the human city.
Returning from the city,
To the pleasure park’s pavilion,
He lay down, like a king of gods,
On a most excellent bed.
Sundarī, and the city,🔽And the dancing and singing,
And the friends and relatives,
And went forth with a resolute heart.
First I will see my son Rāhula,
And then I will go forth,
Thinking thus he came
To the house of Yaśodharā.
Placing his foot on the threshold,🔽He entered the door-way,
And looking about he saw
His son with his mother.
I will take him and go away,🔽So he thought to himself;
But the queen, having awakened,
Would not let him go forth.🔽I will throw Rāhula to the Buddha,
So he thought to himself;
And mounting Kaṇṭhaka,
He went forth from that place.🔽The devas opened the door-way
And the door-way of the courtyard;
A thousand jewelled lamps
Were lit in the sky.

analyzed: mā anikkhamassu siddhattha  itas tvam satta medine
translated: Do not go forth, O Siddhattha,
From here you will become a universal monarch,
So said Māra, the lord of the Paranirmitavaśavartin devas.
Māra, I know you well,
Thus spoke the Buddha, and went forth;
Having thus driven away Māra,
He went on his way rejoicing.
Having reached the bank of the river Anomā,
And again to the city of Rājagaha;
And the city of Bimbā to see Channa,
And to see Devilā.🔽He cut off the garland🔽Perfumed with sweet scents,
With a sharp razor-edged knife,
And threw it up into the air.

analyzed: aṭṭha seṭṭha parikkhāre  dhārā itvā a brahmunā ābhate
translated: Having borne the eight chief requisites,🔽Which were radiant like Brahmā,
Having abandoned the royal requisites,
He went forth for the sake of asceticism.
Performing difficult deeds,
Exerting himself for six years,
With coarse food and drink,🔽He nourished his body in the forest.
On the full moon of the month of Visākha,
Taking the bowl filled with milk-rice
Offered by Sujātā,
He went to the river Nerañjarā.
On the bank of the Nerañjarā,🔽Having heard the supreme exertion,
He went by the excellent path
To the Bodhi Tree.

analyzed: jaya asanepallaṅkamhi  ṭhitaḥ dhi ṭhesi dhi itimā
translated: On the victorious seat and couch,🔽Standing, he resolved thus:
“I will not abandon my exertion

He should be enlightened in the Buddha’s path,
the depth of the Victor’s Dhamma;
having considered this, he should teach,
without any hesitation.
Then Brahmā Sahampati,
requested the teaching;
therefore the Best of Men,
turned the Dhamma Wheel.
The One who is Fully Enlightened for ten years,
on the full moon day of the excellent month of Phagguna,
went to the city of the Sakyans,
with his disciples in front of him.
In the assembly of the kinsmen,
he caused a cool rain to fall;

Having gone with a pair of disciples,

With the net of his knowledge,
the Lord of the world, the Seer of all,

Having seen the people to be awakened,
in the succession of world-spheres,

the Supreme Buddha, the one with good awakening.
Some Brahmas beginning with Baka,
and Yakkhas beginning with Alavaka,

and Rākṣhasas beginning with Sūciloma.
Some ascetics beginning with Jāṇussoṇi,

analyzed: buddhām ayaṃtim aññante  titthiyena ika laddhike
translated: They think this is the Buddha,🔽and some Titthiyas are conceited,
the one with the best of the tamed and the tamer,
the one who crushes the doctrines of others.

surrounded by the radiance of the Buddha,
from the crest-jewel to the soles of the feet.

aggregates of the Dhamma,
for fifty-three years,
And the one called Tilokā.
Performing the Buddha’s duties,
I carry the excellent welfare of the world;
I release beings from the bonds of existence,
And always pass away in time.
Where the protector of the eighty (disciples)
Was extinguished in the excellent Jeta’s Grove,
In the delightful Mahāsāla forest,
In the town of the Mallas here.
In the presence of the mass of flames,
The disciple named Jāle,
Was extinguished of conditioned things,
Showing the impermanence of all things.”

analyzed: namaḥ te bhagavān atha  namaḥ utejayataṃjaya
translated: “Homage to the Blessed Protector,🔽Homage to the Victorious One,
Homage to the one endowed with wisdom,
Homage to the delight of the world.”
Paying Homage to the Buddha
Having passed away from the world of the gods,
In the womb of Mahāmāyā;
He was born in the early morning,
I pay homage to this best of the Sakyas.

translated: On the tenth day of the waxing moon,

On the bright fortnight in Lumbini,
I pay homage to him, revered by the world.
